Vietnam War.passage:
History of the Vietnam War
The Vietnam War, officially the War in Vietnam, was a long-standing civil war fought primarily between the communist-backed North Vietnamese forces and the anti-communist United States Armed Forces. It was the longest military conflict in the history of the United States, and the most costly in terms of casualties, both for the Americans and the Vietnamese. The war was fought between the years of 1955 and 1975 and resulted in a large number of losses on both sides, with more than 58,000 American deaths and at least 5,000 civilian and military Vietnamese deaths. The war was a significant factor in the Vietnamization of the U.S. military. U.S.passage: "The United States is the world's oldest national anthem and the country's national flag. The flag, featuring a red, white, and blue square with a number of stars representing each state in the union, was first introduced to the American public at a July 4, 1777, dinner hosted by John Adams and his wife, Abigail, at the Philadelphia home of Judith and Samuel Revere. The anthem, "The Star-Spangled Banner" (a nickname for the flag), is also the title of the song performed in this tradition. The song is a variation on the British national anthem "God Save the King." The anthem was written in 1812 by Francis Scott Key, an American lawyer, poet and member of the Maryland State Legislature, during a hurricane near Fort McHenry in Baltimore. The song was adapted from an English folk song to the tune of a tune associated with the British and Irish folk ballad "The Bonny Earl of Murray." The melody was originally written by English composer George Frideric Handel and is also known in the United States as the tune for "Rule, Brittania" and as the theme for the musical God Save the King. The song is performed in the U.S. flag on Independence Day, and the flag is flown daily on the U.S. government buildings, the U.S. military installations and on U.S. embassies worldwide.

Taliban.passage: In 1996, the Taliban were brought to power by the Afghan government by means of a military coup. The Taliban, who were in exile in Pakistan since 1992, and have the support of Iran, declared that all the country must recognize them as the governing power of Afghanistan. This caused a civil war in Afghanistan. In 1998 the Taliban began a “purge” of anyone who didn’t pledge loyalty to their governing body. In 2001, the Taliban was driven from power by the US and coalition forces.

Afghanistan.passage:
The US-led invasion in 2001, and its subsequent occupation of Afghanistan has led to a massive increase in civilian deaths. It has caused death and injuries in the "coalition" forces and also has been criticized for civilian deaths. The number of civilian deaths in 2009 was 2,200, which was the highest in 2009, and is also still one of the highest of any year. The number of deaths attributed to "civilian casualties" has remained between 3,000 and 5,000 per year, while the number of deaths attributed to U.S. forces has risen between 1,000 and 2,500 per year. According to the United Nations' report on "Extra-Judicial Killings", more than 21,000 civilians died between 2002 and 2006 as a result of the United States-led occupation in Afghanistan. More than 50 percent of the deaths were attributed to U.S. forces. This is a photograph from the 2001 invasion:
It's a disturbing photograph because it depicts a soldier shooting at a man running away. If you look closely you can see that the man is only running away because the tank is firing at him. The reason I put this on here is because the occupation is still going on, and it's one of the most dangerous places to be in the world for civilians.

the United States.passage:
“In 2006, an estimated 2,776,000 abortions were performed in the United States. By contrast, in 1950 the estimated number was 1,250,000, which is the equivalent of over 8 million abortions a year.”
This is a shocking statistic, and it’s made even more disturbing when you realize that there are still people in this country that take exception to the notion that women (and men) have the right to make decisions about their bodies and when they reproduce. A woman’s choice regarding abortion, or not having one, should be respected, and it is no place for government intervention. For those who say that the government should have “morality laws” regarding sexual intercourse, I say “no, I don’t want government interference. Period.” I believe that this nation, and the people of this nation, are better off with the government keeping their nose out of our business. So to those who believe that a woman should not have the right to choose what she does with her own body, I say “just don’t have sex.” Problem solved.

qae_pairs.question: How many abortions were performed in the United States in 1950?
qae_pairs.explanation: 1,250,000 abortions were performed in 1950.
